channel.title: The Complete List of Technical Acronyms And Their Definitions on Tech Terminologies
channel.description: Recent content in The Complete List of Technical Acronyms And Their Definitions on Tech Terminologies

item.title: What is SATA (Serial ATA)?
item.description: Serial ATA (SATA) is a computer bus interface that connects host bus adapters to mass storage devices such as hard drives and optical drives.

item.title: What is Ultra DMA (Ultra Direct Memory Access)?
item.description: Ultra DMA (Ultra Direct Memory Access) is a data transfer technology used in computers to improve the speed of data transfer between the computer’s hard disk drive and the system memory.

item.title: What is XMP (Extensible Metadata Platform)?
item.description: XMP (Extensible Metadata Platform) is a standard for storing and organizing metadata (data about data) in a digital file.

item.title: What is EXIF (Exchangeable Image File Format)?
item.description: EXIF, or Exchangeable Image File Format, is a type of metadata that is embedded in a digital image file.

item.title: What is CDFS (Compact Disc File System)?
item.description: The Compact Disc File System, also known as CDFS, is a file system used to store and access data on a compact disc.

item.title: What is a CLI (Command-Line Interface)?
item.description: A command-line interface (CLI) is a text-based interface that allows users to interact with a computer by typing commands and receiving output.

item.title: What is a GUI (Graphical User Interface)?
item.description: A GUI, or Graphical User Interface, is a type of interface that allows users to interact with electronic devices through visual elements such as icons and graphics, rather than typing commands in a command-line interface.

item.title: What is a Codec?
item.description: A codec is a device or software that is used to encode or decode a digital data stream or signal.

item.title: What is NoSQL Database?
item.description: NoSQL, also known as “Not Only SQL,” is a type of database that is designed to handle large volumes of structured, semi-structured, or unstructured data.

item.title: What is a DNS (Domain Name System)?
item.description: A Domain Name System (DNS) is a decentralized system that translates human-readable domain names, such as example.

item.title: What is Adware?
item.description: Adware, short for “advertising-supported software,” is a type of software that displays advertisements on a computer or mobile device.

item.title: What is 5G?
item.description: 5G is the fifth generation of mobile network technology that is designed to provide faster and more reliable internet connectivity to devices such as smartphones, tablets, and laptops.

item.title: What is 4G?
item.description: 4G is a mobile telecommunications technology that lets smartphones and tablets connect to the internet at high speeds.

item.title: What is the 404 Error (Not Found)?
item.description: The 404 error is an HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) status code that indicates that the server was unable to find the requested resource.

item.title: What is the 403 Error (Forbidden)?
item.description: A 403 error is an HTTP status code that indicates that a client is forbidden from accessing a requested resource.

item.title: What is 3G?
item.description: 3G, or third generation, is a generation of wireless mobile telecommunications technology.

item.title: What is NBA (Network Behavior Analysis)?
item.description: Network behavior analysis is a cybersecurity technique that involves the continuous monitoring and analysis of network traffic and activity to identify unusual or malicious behavior.

item.title: What is CDN (Content Delivery Network)?
item.description: A Content Delivery Network (CDN) is a globally distributed network of servers that work together to deliver content to users as efficiently as possible.

item.title: What is UPS (Uninterruptible Power Supply)?
item.description: An uninterruptible power supply (UPS) is a device that provides backup power to a computer, server, or other electronic equipment in the event of an interruption or fluctuation in the main power supply.

item.title: What is NFC (Near Field Communication)?
item.description: Near Field Communication (NFC) is a short-range wireless technology that allows for the exchange of data or power between devices.

item.title: What is ICT (Information and Communications Technology)?
item.description: Information and communications technology, or ICT, refers to the various technologies and tools used to facilitate the exchange of information and communication.

item.title: What is CGI (Computer-generated Imagery)?
item.description: Computer-generated imagery (CGI) is a technique used to create digital images or animations using computer software.

item.title: What is APU (Accelerated Processing Unit)?
item.description: An APU, or accelerated processing unit, is a type of processor that combines a CPU and GPU on a single chip.
